001package imagingbook.lib.math.eigen;
002
003import static imagingbook.lib.math.Arithmetic.sqr;
004
005import java.util.ArrayList;
006import java.util.Arrays;
007import java.util.Collections;
008import java.util.Comparator;
009import java.util.List;
010
011import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.EigenDecomposition;
012import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.MatrixUtils;
013
014import imagingbook.lib.math.Arithmetic;
015import imagingbook.lib.math.Matrix;
016
017/**
018 * Calculates eigenvalues and eigenvectors of square matrices of arbitrary size.
019 * Eigenvalues are sorted by magnitude (in descending order). A matrix may have
020 * complex eigenvalues but only real eigenvalues (and their associated
021 * eigenvectors) are considered. Uses class {@link EigenDecomposition} of the
022 * Apache Commons Math (3) library.
023 * <br>
024 * Usage example (retrieving all eigenvalues and associated eigenvectors):
025 * <pre>
026 * double[][] A = {
027 *      { 5, 2, 0, 1 },
028 *      { 2, 5, 0, 7 },
029 *      { -3, 4, 6, 0 },
030 *      { 1, 2, 3, 4 }};
031 * 
032 * RealEigensolver solver = new EigensolverNxN(A);
033 * 
034 * double[] eigenvals = solver.getEigenvalues();
035 * for (int k = 0; k &lt; solver.getSize(); k++) {
036 *      double lambda = solver.getEigenvalue(k);
037 *      if (!Double.isNaN(lambda)) {
038 *              double[] x = solver.getEigenvector(k);
039 *              ...
040 *      }
041 * }</pre>
042 * 
043 * @author WB
044 * @version 2021/04/20
045 */
046public class EigensolverNxN implements RealEigensolver {
047
048        private final EigenDecomposition ed;
049        private final int n;
050        private final double[] eVals;
051        private final int[] permutation;
052
053        /**
054         * Constructor, takes a NxN (square) matrix.
055         * @param A a NxN matrix
056         */
057        public EigensolverNxN(double[][] A) {
058                if (!Matrix.isSquare(A)) {
059                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("matrix A must be square");
060                }
061                this.n = A.length;
062                this.ed = new EigenDecomposition(MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(A));
063                this.eVals = new double[A.length];
064                this.permutation = sortEigenvalues(ed.getRealEigenvalues(), ed.getImagEigenvalues());
065                //print();
066        }
067        
068        @Override
069        public int getSize() {
070                return n;
071        }
072        
073        @Override
074        public boolean isReal() {
075                return !ed.hasComplexEigenvalues();
076        }
077
078        @Override
079        public double[] getEigenvalues() {
080                return eVals;
081        }
082
083        @Override
084        public double getEigenvalue(int k) {
085                return eVals[k];
086        }
087
088        @Override
089        public double[] getEigenvector(int k) {
090                return ed.getEigenvector(permutation[k]).toArray();
091        }
092        
093        // -----------------------------------------------------
094        
095        /**
096         * Sorts eigenvalues by magnitude (in descending order, including complex eigenvalues),
097         * inserts sorted values into {@link #eVals} (NaN for complex eigenvalues),
098         * and returns the associated permutation array.
099         * @param re real parts of all eigenvalues
100         * @param im imaginary parts of all eigenvalues
101         * @return the permutation array for sorting by magnitude
102         */
103        private int[] sortEigenvalues(double[] re, double[] im) {
104                final int n = re.length;
105                double[] mag = new double[n];
106                for (int k = 0; k < n; k++) {
107                        mag[k] = Math.sqrt(sqr(re[k]) + sqr(im[k]));
108                }
109                
110                // inspired by https://stackoverflow.com/a/11998394
111                List<Integer> indices = new ArrayList<>(mag.length);
112                for (int i = 0; i < mag.length; i++) {
113                        indices.add(i);
114                }
115                
116                Comparator<Integer> comparator = new Comparator<Integer>() {
117                        @Override
118                        public int compare(Integer a, Integer b) {
119                                return Double.compare(mag[b], mag[a]);
120                        }
121                };
122
123                Collections.sort(indices, comparator);
124                int[] perm = indices.stream().mapToInt(Integer::intValue).toArray();
125                
126                // Rearrange 'eVals' and replace complex eigenvalues by NaN:
127                for (int k = 0; k < n; k++) {
128                        int j = perm[k];
129                        eVals[k] = (Arithmetic.isZero(im[j])) ? re[j] : Double.NaN;
130                }
131                return perm;
132        }
133        
134
135        @SuppressWarnings("unused")
136        private void print() {
137                System.out.println("hasComplexEigenvalues = " + ed.hasComplexEigenvalues());
138                double[] evalsR = ed.getRealEigenvalues();
139                double[] evalsI = ed.getImagEigenvalues();
140                System.out.format("evalsR = %s\n", Arrays.toString(evalsR));
141                System.out.format("evalsI = %s\n", Arrays.toString(evalsI));
142                
143                for (int k = 0; k < evalsR.length; k++) {
144                        double[] evecR = ed.getEigenvector(k).toArray();
145                        System.out.format("%d: eval=%f | evec=%s\n", k, getEigenvalue(k), Arrays.toString(getEigenvector(k)));
146                }
147        }
148
149        // -------------------------------------------------------------------------
150        
151        /**
152         * @param args args
153         * @hidden
154         */
155        public static void main(String[] args) {
156//              double[][] A = {
157//                              {3, -2},
158//                              {-4, 1}};
159//              double[][] A = {        // no real eigenvalues
160//                              {0, -1},
161//                              {2, 0}};
162//              double[][] A = {        // no real eigenvalues
163//                              {4, -1},
164//                              {2, 4}};
165//              double[][] A = {
166//                              {5, 2, 0},
167//                              {2, 5, 0},
168//                              {-3, 4, 6}};
169                double[][] A = {        // 2 real eigenvalues
170                                {5, 2, 0, 1},
171                                {2, 5, 0, 7},
172                                {-3, 4, 6, 0},
173                                {1 , 2, 3, 4}};
174                
175                
176                System.out.println("A = \n" + Matrix.toString(A));
177                RealEigensolver solver = new EigensolverNxN(A); 
178
179                System.out.println("isReal = " + solver.isReal());
180                double[] eigenvals = solver.getEigenvalues();
181                System.out.println("evals = " + Matrix.toString(eigenvals));
182                for (int k = 0; k < solver.getSize(); k++) {
183                        double lambda = solver.getEigenvalue(k);
184                        if (!Double.isNaN(lambda)) {
185                                double[] x = solver.getEigenvector(k);
186                                System.out.format("λ_%d = %.6f\n", k, lambda);
187                                System.out.format("x_%d = %s\n", k, Matrix.toString(x));
188                                System.out.format("   M*x = %s\n", Matrix.toString(Matrix.multiply(A, x)));
189                                System.out.format("   λ*M = %s\n", Matrix.toString(Matrix.multiply(lambda, x)));
190                        }
191                }
192        }
193}
